{{Infobox NRHP | name = Corcoran Gallery of Art | nrhp_type = nhl | image = Corcoran Gallery of Art - Washington DC - DSC01051.JPG | caption = | location = 500 17th St., NW
[[Washington, D.C.]] | coordinates = {{coord|38.8958|-77.0399|region:US-DC_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = United States Washington, D.C. central#Washington, D.C.#USA | area = | built = | architect =Ernest Flagg | architecture = Beaux Arts | added = May 6, 1971 | refnum =71000997 | nearest_city = | designated_nrhp_type=April 27, 1992 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | mpsub = | governing_body = }} The '''Corcoran Gallery of Art''' was an art museum in [[Washington, D.C.]] that is now the location of the [[Corcoran School of the Arts and Design]], a part of the [[George Washington University]]. The Corcoran School, founded in 1878, hosts exhibitions by its students and visiting artists and offers degrees in Fine Art, Photojournalism, Interaction Design, Interior Architecture, etc. Prior to the Gallery's closing, it was one of the oldest privately supported cultural institutions in the United States. Starting in 1890, a museum school, later known as the [[Corcoran School of the Arts and Design|Corcoran College of Art + Design]], co-existed with the gallery. The museum's main focus was [[Visual arts of the United States|American art]]. In 2014, after decades of financial problems and mismanagement, the Corcoran was dissolved by court order. A new non-profit was established and the Corcoran's $2 billion, 17,000 piece art collection was given away for free to the National Gallery of Art (NGA). What works the NGA did not accession were donated to cultural institutions throughout Washington, D.C. and across the country. The Corcoran School of Art and Design was given to [[George Washington University]] (GWU) along with the $200 million historic 17th street building along with $50 million. ==History== ===Founding=== [[File:USA-Corcoran Gallery of Art2.jpg|thumb|left|Entrance of the former Corcoran Gallery of Art]] When the gallery was founded in 1869 by [[William Wilson Corcoran]], the co-founder of [[Riggs Bank]], it was one of the first [[fine art]] galleries in the country.{{cite web |url=http://www.ability.org.uk/art.html |title=Art And Museums |accessdate=19 December 2010 }} Corcoran established the gallery, supported with an [[financial endowment|endowment]], "for the perpetual establishment and encouragement of the Fine Arts." While an independent institution, the Corcoran was the oldest and largest non-federal [[art museum]] in the [[District of Columbia]]. Its mission was "dedicated to art and used solely for the purpose of encouraging the American genius." The Corcoran Gallery of Art was originally located at 17th Street and [[Pennsylvania Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Pennsylvania Avenue]], in the building that now houses the [[Renwick Gallery]]. Construction of that building started before the [[American Civil War|Civil War]]. The building, near completion, was used by the government as a warehouse during the Civil War. It was finally completed in 1874 and the gallery opened to the public.{{cite book |author=Reed, Robert |title=Old Washington, D.C. in Early Photographs: 1846–1932 |publisher=Dover Publications |year=1980 |page=127}} By 1897, the Corcoran Gallery collection outgrew the space of its original building. A new building was constructed, designed by [[Ernest Flagg]] in a [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] style. The 135,000 square feet (12,500 m²) building was built to house an expanded Corcoran collection in addition to the nascent school, which had been formally founded in 1890. The new building features a pair of bronze statues, the [[Canova Lions]], at its entrance. These lions were purchased at auction by the Corcoran Galley in 1888 and placed in front of the museum at its original location. The iconic bronze castings were moved to their current location in 1897 when the museum moved to its current building at 17th Street and New York Avenue.{{Cite web|url=http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WMJN4H_Corcoran_Gallery_of_Art_Lions_Washington_DC|title=Corcoran Gallery of Art Lions - Washington, D.C. - Exact Replicas on Waymarking.com|website=www.waymarking.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-06}} === Years of growth === In 1928, the art collection of former Senator [[William A. Clark]] joined the Corcoran in a new wing designed by Charles Adam Platt, and inaugurated by President Calvin Coolidge. For decades, the Corcoran examined the possibility of adding on a final wing which would complete the campus footprint. These plans abruptly ended in 2005 after a [[Frank O. Gehry]] -designed wing was scrapped due to lack of funding, and the remainder of the available property was sold to a private developer.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/05/27/AR2005052701609.html |title=Crushed |accessdate=9 September 2015}} Throughout the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, the gallery continued to display its main collection from Corcoran, Clark, and a few select major donors. At its peak, the museum owned a significant collection including work from [[Rembrandt Peale]], [[Eugène Delacroix]], [[Edgar Degas]], [[Thomas Gainsborough]], [[John Singer Sargent]], [[Claude Monet]], [[Mariano Fortuny (painter)|Mariano Fortuny]], [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Edward Hopper]], [[Willem de Kooning]], [[Joan Mitchell]], [[Gene Davis (painter)|Gene Davis]], and many others. Space was always a challenge - only a small percentage of the gallery's permanent collection was able to be displayed in the confines of the 17th street gallery, which shared its roughly 140,000 square feet with the art school. === Mapplethorpe controversy === In 1989, the Corcoran Gallery of Art had agreed to host a traveling solo exhibit of [[Robert Mapplethorpe]]'s works. Mapplethorpe decided to show a new series that he had explored shortly before his death, ''[[The Perfect Moment|Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment]]'' curated by Janet Kardon of the [[Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia|Institute of Contemporary Art]].{{cite web |url=http://www.icaphila.org/news/pdf/mapplethorpe_pr.pdf |title=Imperfect Moments: Mapplethorpe and Censorship Twenty Years Later |publisher= Institute of Contemporary Art }} Several Trustees of the Corcoran and U.S. Representatives Dick Armey (TX) and Jesse Helms (NC) were horrified when the works were revealed to them, and the museum director, Christina Orr-Cahall succumbed to pressure and cancelled the exhibit, which had already been announced to its members through an exhibition preview invitation.{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1212527.html |title=Corcoran Offers `Regret' on Mapplethorpe; Statement Promises Support for Art, Artists and Artistic Freedom |work=[[The Washington Post]] Article |date=September 19, 1989 |first=Elizabeth |last=Kastor |accessdate=December 19, 2010}} The Coalition of Washington Artists organized a demonstration to protest the Corcoran Gallery's cancellation of the exhibit. An estimated 700 people attended the demonstration.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/01/arts/crowd-at-corcoran-protests-mapplethorpe-cancellation.html |title=Crowd at Corcoran Protests Mapplethorpe Cancellation |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Barbara |last=Gamarekian |date=July 1, 1989 |accessdate=December 19, 2010}} In June 1989, [[pop art]]ist [[Lowell Blair Nesbitt]] became involved in the controversy over Mapplethorpe's work. It was at this time that Nesbitt, a long-time friend of Mapplethorpe, revealed that he had a $1.5 million bequest to the museum in his will. Nesbitt publicly promised that if the museum refused to host the exhibition he would revoke his [[bequest]]. The Corcoran refused and Nesbitt bequeathed the money to the [[Phillips Collection]] instead. After the Corcoran cancelled the Mapplethorpe exhibition, the underwriters of the exhibition went to the nonprofit [[Washington Project for the Arts]],{{cite web |url=http://www.law.indiana.edu/fclj/pubs/v47/no2/fitzpat.html |title=The Sensitive Society |first=James F. |last=Fitzpatrick |page=FCLJ Vol 47 No 2 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080613072721/http://www.law.indiana.edu/fclj/pubs/v47/no2/fitzpat.html |archivedate=2008-06-13 |df= }} which showed the controversial images in its own space from July 21 to August 13, 1989, to large crowds.{{cite news |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73897099.html?dids=73897099:73897099&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Sep+6%2C+1989&author=Judd+Tully&pub=The+Washington+Post+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&edition=&startpage=b.01&desc=Corcoran+Cut+From+Painter%27s+Will%3BLowell+Nesbitt%27s+Mapplethorpe+Protest |title=Corcoran Cut From Painter's Will; Lowell Nesbitt's Mapplethorpe Protest | first=Judd | last=Tully |date=6 September 1989}}{{cite web |url=http://photography-now.net/listings/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=354&Itemid=334 |title=Robert Mapplethorpe |accessdate=December 19, 2010 }} The 1990 [[National Endowment for the Arts|NEA]] Appropriations Bill included language against "obscene" work.{{cite web |url=http://www.publiceye.org/theocrat/Mapplethorpe_Chrono.html |title=The Mapplethorpe Censorship Controversy. Chronology of events. The 1989–1991 battles |first=Margaret |last=Quigley |accessdate= December 19, 2010}} As a result of the controversy, more than a dozen artists canceled exhibitions{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1209019.html |title=Artists Cancel Exhibitions At Corcoran; Mapplethorpe Case Prompts Boycott |work=The Washington Post|date=August 30, 1989 |first=Paul |last=Richard |accessdate=December 19, 2010 }} while the director, Christina Orr-Cahall, resigned and moved to the [[Norton Museum of Art]].{{cite news |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1990-02-11/entertainment/9002093777_1_cahall-corcoran-mapplethorpe |title=Out Of The Frying Pan, Into West Palm |date=February 11, 1990|first= Chuck |last=Twardy |work=[[Orlando Sentinel]] |accessdate=December 19, 2010}} === Final years === [[File:Gallery display of American paintings formerly in the collection of the Corcoran Gallery of Art, now at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C.jpg|thumb|By 2018, artwork accessioned by the National Gallery of Art from the Corcoran collection had been incorporated into displays at the Gallery; these four paintings are among those currently visible in the rooms dedicated to American art.]] In its final years, the museum and its affiliated art and design college [[Corcoran School of the Arts and Design]] together had a staff of about 140 and an operating budget of about $24 million. Revenue came from grants and contributions, admissions fees, tuition, membership dues, gift shop and restaurant sales, and an [[Financial endowment|endowment]] worth around $30 million. In February 2001, two [[America Online|AOL]] executives ([[Robert W. Pittman]] and [[Barry Schuler]]) and their wives donated $30 million to the museum, its largest single donation since its founding. In 2014, following decades of financial problems, the Corcoran Trustees chose to break the founder's deed of trust by going to court to have the Corcoran dissolved. Following a court order dissolving the city's oldest independent museum, the trustees gave the former college of art and design, the $200 million Beaux Arts building, and $50 million to [[George Washington University]] to renovate the facility and operate the school programs. The 17,000 piece art collection worth $2 billion was donated to the [[National Gallery of Art]].{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/corcoran-gallery-george-washington-university-and-national-gallery-close-deal-to-transform-corcoran/2014/05/15/4ddba908-dc4a-11e3-b745-87d39690c5c0_story.html | newspaper=The Washington Post | first=David | last=Montgomery | title=Corcoran Gallery, GWU and National Gallery close deal to transform Corcoran | date=February 21, 2014}} In the beginning of 2018, the director of the [[Corcoran School of the Arts and Design]] officially disclosed plans for the [[National Gallery of Art]] to bring art back to the second floor of the Flagg building.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/arts/article/20987508/is-a-renovation-at-the-george-washington-university-making-its-students-sick | newspaper=Washington City Paper | first=Kriston | last=Capps | title=Is a Renovation at the Corcoran's Flagg Building Making Its Students Sick? | date=January 4, 2018}} == Interior == Flagg also designed the interior of the building. When one enters the building's front doors on 17th Street, they first enter the 170 ft x 50 ft atrium. The vast space, separated into three connected sections, consists of forty limestone columns and twin skylights (to light the intended display of sculptures). The Beaux-Arts-inspired room rises two interior stories and has housed exhibit space and other uses.National Register of Historic Places nomination, https://dcpreservation-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Corcoran-Gallery-of-Art-Interior-Nomination.pdf Directly across the atrium from the front entrance stands the grand staircase, leading to the second floor. Low rise stairs, sixteen feet wide, are watched over by six statues on pedestals atop marble platforms, and lead to a landing halfway to the second floor. Hold onto the brass-topped railing for balance. From the grand staircase one can access the rotunda and the second story level of the atrium, including a bridge that heads across the atrium back towards the direction of the front door. Gallery space exists throughout. Back on the first floor, three galleries lead from the atrium (originally there were seven). The second floor originally had eight galleries. The rotunda came later, designed by [[Charles A. Platt|Charles Platt]] in 1925. Forty eight feet wide, the room's domed ceiling culminates in an oculus skylight. Reminiscent of the [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon]], the space offers an exquisite entry to the building's Clark Wing. An observer would access a marble floored, square, dark staircase hall with wood panels to reach the Clark Wing galleries. At the northern end of the building, the Hemicycle's unusual shape fills the angle created by New York Avenue and 17th Street. The space is the auditorium, being 67 ft x 45 ft with a 300-person capacity. The Salon Doré appears on the building's opposite side. Also referred to as the "French Room," it displays intricate French decorations; it was designed in the early 1700s by [[Jean Chalgrin|Jean‐François‐Thérèse Chalgrin]] and was moved from Paris to the United States sometime before 1904. In 2015, preservationists added the interior portions of the Corcoran Gallery to the National Register of Historic Places (the exterior had been listed in 1971). The interior nomination includes the grand staircase, atrium, rotunda, gallery, and other notable spaces.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/preservationists-file-to-protect-corcoran/2012/10/01/d8a6e728-0bd6-11e2-a310-2363842b7057_story.html|title=Preservationists file to protect Corcoran|last=https://www.facebook.com/david.montgomery.5682944|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-07-11}}{{Cite news|url=https://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/04/24/landmark-status-for-corcoran-gallery-of-art-interior/|title=Landmark Status for Corcoran Gallery of Art Interior|last=Wolfe|first=Jonathan|work=ArtsBeat|access-date=2018-07-11|language=en}} ==See also== *[[Corcoran School of the Arts and Design]] *[[Jacob Guptil Fletcher]] '''Dewey-free''' (also '''Dewey free''', '''Dewey-less''', or '''word-based''') refers to [[Library classification|library classification schemes]] developed as alternatives to [[Dewey Decimal Classification]] (DDC). Dewey-free systems are often based on the [[BISAC]] subject headings developed by the [[Book Industry Study Group]], and are typically implemented in libraries with smaller collections. Instead of using numerical notation to indicate a document's shelving location, Dewey-free systems organize documents alphabetically by natural language words. Dewey-free systems have been implemented in both [[Public library|public]] and [[School library|school]] libraries.
==Motivations==
A primary motivation for the development of Dewey-free systems is to eliminate DDC's numerical notation, which many library patrons find intimidating. Abandoning numerical notation in favor of natural language words may also facilitate browsing.<ref name=lj>{{cite journal|last1=Fister|first1=Barbara|title=The Dewey Dilemma|journal=Library Journal|date=2009|volume=134|issue=16|pages=22–25}}</ref>
Adoption of Dewey-free classification is often seen as part of a greater trend of using a "bookstore model" to deliver library services. This trend gained traction in 1998 with an article by Los Angeles librarian Steve Coffman.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Coffman|first1=Steve|title=What if you ran your library like a bookstore?|journal=American Libraries|date=March 1998|pages=40–46}}</ref> While some librarians see this as a beneficial approach that will make patrons more comfortable and increase circulation statistics, others disagree with the approach, particularly as large bookstores such as [[Borders Group]] have met severe financial challenges.
Many Dewey-free proponents believe that Dewey is outdated and ill-suited for non-academic environments.<ref name=lj /><ref name=gibson /> DDC organizes documents not only by subject, but also by academic discipline.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hope|first1=Olson|title=Sameness and difference: a cultural foundation of classification|journal=Library Resources and Technical Services|date=2001|volume=45|issue=3|page=117|url=http://www.ala.org/alcts/files/resources/lrts/archive/45n3.pdf}}</ref> This leads to materials on the same topic being filed in wildly disparate locations. For example, Dewey places books about railroad trains in both the 380s and the 620s.<ref name=metis /> The discipline-based orientation is also problematic for categorizing interdisciplinary works<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Searing|first1=Susan E.|title=How Libraries Cope with Interdisciplinarity: The Case of Women's Studies|journal=Issues in integrative studies|date=1992|volume=10|page=8}}</ref> and non-academic titles, which make up the bulk of most public libraries' non-fiction holdings.
DDC has also faced a number of critiques for its biases. Scholars and catalogers have specifically criticized its marginalization of [[developing countries]] and continents,<ref name=afolabi>{{cite journal|last1=Afolabi|first1=M|title=Spiritual matters: Provision for independent African churches in general classification schemes.|journal=International Classification|date=1992|volume=19|issue=4|pages=210–213}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Iwuji|first1=H.O.M.|title=Africana in LC and DD classification schemes: A need for an Africana scheme?|journal=Journal of Librarianship and Information Science|date=1989|volume=21|issue=1|pages=1–18|doi=10.1177/096100068902100101}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=McConnell|first1=Fraiser|title=Classification of Melanesia|journal=Cataloging & Classification Quarterly|date=13 August 1984|volume=5|issue=1|pages=53–60|doi=10.1300/J104v05n01_04}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=McConnell|first1=Fraiser|title=Languages of Melanesia|journal=Cataloging & Classification Quarterly|date=10 May 1985|volume=5|issue=3|pages=57–66|doi=10.1300/J104v05n03_05}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=McConnell|first1=Fraiser|title=Peoples of Melanesia|journal=Cataloging & Classification Quarterly|date=2 October 1985|volume=5|issue=4|pages=47–51|doi=10.1300/J104v05n04_04}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kua|first1=Eunice|title=Non-Western Languages and Literatures in the Dewey Decimal Classification Scheme|journal=Libri|date=2004|volume=54|pages=256–265|url=http://www.librijournal.org/pdf/2004-4pp256-265.pdf|doi=10.1515/libr.2004.256}}</ref> Christian-centrism,<ref name=afolabi /> racism,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Beall|first1=Julianne|title=Racially Mixed People, DDC Table 5 Ethnic and National Groups, and MARC 21 Bibliographic Format Field 083|journal=Cataloging & Classification Quarterly|volume=47|issue=7|pages=657–670|doi=10.1080/01639370903112005}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Furner|first1=Jonathan|title=Dewey Deracialized: A Critical Race-Theoretic Perspective|journal=Knowledge Organization|date=2007|volume=34|issue=3|pages=144–168}}</ref> sexism,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Steinberg|title=Classified women|journal=Librarians for social change|volume=5}}</ref> homophobia,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wolf|first1=S|editor1-last=West|editor1-first=Celeste|editor1-link=Celeste_West|title=Revolting librarians|publisher=Booklegger Press|location=San Francisco|pages=39–44|chapter=Sex and the single cataloger: New thoughts on some unthinkable subjects}}</ref> and marginalization of intersex people.<ref>{{cite book|last=Christensen|first=Ben|editor1-last=Greenblatt|editor1-first=Ellen|title=Serving LGBTIQ Library and Archives Users : Essays on Outreach, Service, Collections and Access|date=2011|publisher=McFarland & Company|isbn=0786448946|pages=201–211|chapter=Interfiling Intersex: How Dewey Classifies Intersex in Theory and in Practice}}</ref> Some proponents of Dewey-free systems suggest that abandoning DDC in favor of new schemes may address these problems, but the literature doesn't include any analysis of BISAC Subject Headings for these issues, nor have any Dewey-free libraries documented strategies for addressing these issues within the taxonomies they have devised.
Librarians who work with children point to additional benefits within their collections. They note that school library workers often have little support and few resources for teaching the DDC system to children. The numbers themselves are often opaque to younger students, who typically don't learn about decimals until late in elementary school.<ref name=gibson>{{cite journal|last1=Gibson|first1=Marjorie|title=Innovative 21st Century Classification Schemes for Elementary School Libraries|journal=Feliciter|date=2011|volume=57|issue=2|pages=48–61|url=http://www.cla.ca/Content/NavigationMenu/Resources/Feliciter/PastIssues/2011/Vol57No2/Feliciter2_Vol_57_2011_web.pdf|accessdate=13 June 2014}}</ref>
==Adoption== In the 1970s and 1980s, public libraries in the United Kingdom and United States designed new "reader-interest classification" systems as alternatives to DDC. These systems organized materials in ways that are intuitive to non-academic users and employed modern terminology, resulting in collections that are more browsable. However, a lack of standardization led libraries to abandon these systems. Dewey-free classification schemes can be seen as new cases of reader-interest classification schemes.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Martínez-Ávila|first1=Daniel|last2=San Segundo|first2=Rosa|last3=Olson|first3=Hope A.|title=The Use of BISAC in Libraries as New Cases of Reader-Interest Classifications|journal=Cataloging & Classification Quarterly|volume=52|issue=2|pages=137–155|doi=10.1080/01639374.2013.846284}}</ref>
In 2007, the [[Maricopa County Library District]] announced that its Gilbert Library would abandon DDC in favor of a BISAC-based system.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lynch|first1=Sarah N.|last2=Mulero|first2=Eugene|title=Dewey? At This Library With a Very Different Outlook, They Don't|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/14/us/14dewey.html|work=New York Times|date=14 July 2007}}</ref> The library district reported the change as a success, with non-fiction circulation improving sixfold.<ref name=discord>{{cite news|last1=Lavallee|first1=Andrew|title=Discord over Dewey|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB118340075827155554|accessdate=13 June 2014|work=Wall Street Journal|date=20 July 2007}}</ref>
In 2009, the [[Rangeview Library District]] became the first library district to fully convert to a BISAC-based scheme. Rangeview's classification system, which is branded as "WordThink", is based on BISAC headings.<ref name=anythink>{{cite journal|last1=Oder|first1=Norman|title=In the Country of Anythink|journal=Library Journal|date=15 November 2010|volume=135|issue=19|page=22}}</ref>
In 2011, the librarians at the [[Ethical Culture School]] in New York City developed a Dewey-Free system called [[Metis Classification|Metis]]. The school's novel approach incorporated focus groups of students from Kindergarten through the Fifth Grade in designing the system.<ref name=metis />
The Darien Library in Connecticut employs a hybrid approach to classification. While books are still organized by DDC number, DDC categories are "clumped into eight broad categories," known as glades.<ref name=lj /> A glade groups together books from several Dewey classes that Darien librarians feel may be useful to similar groups. For example, the ''Places'' glade is intended for international travellers, and combines books from the 400s (Languages) and 910s (Travel and Geography).<ref>{{cite web|title=Getting to Know the Glades|url=http://www.darienlibrary.org/node/1706|website=Darien Library|accessdate=13 June 2014}}</ref>
The [[Nyack Library]] used a "marketplace" system similar to Darien's glades.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gray|first1=John|last2=Mahoney|first2=James|title=Nyack Library’s Dewey Decimal Debate|url=http://www.nyacknewsandviews.com/2012/06/nl_deweydecimal_oview/|accessdate=13 June 2014|work=Nyack News and Views|date=23 June 2012}}</ref> However, after complaints from community members, the library reverted to a traditional DDC collection in 2013.
The [[King County Library System]] announced in 2014 that all 48 of its branches will convert their fiction [[picture book]] collections to a Dewey-free subject classification system.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McGowan|first1=Cecilia|title=When Finding Picture Books Really Can Be Child’s Play [presentation]|url=https://sas.elluminate.com/p.jnlp?psid=2014-08-05.0715.M.51A1F6BD288768B43F3C46EBA9B642.vcr&sid=2008170|website=First Tuesdays|publisher=Washington State Library|accessdate=12 August 2014|date=5 August 2014}}</ref>
==Evaluation== There has been very little formal evaluation of Dewey-free systems, even by libraries that have implemented them.<ref name=anythink />
Many libraries point to an increase in circulation statistics—either for a particular topic or for the non-fiction collection as a whole—as a measure of the success of their Dewey-free systems.<ref name=gibson /><ref name=metis>{{cite journal|last1=Kaplan|first1=Tali Balas|last2=Dolloff|first2=Andrea K.|last3=Giffard|first3=Sue|last4=Still-Schiff|first4=Jennifer|title=Are Dewey’s Days Numbered?: Libraries Nationwide Are Ditching the Old Classification System|journal=School Library Journal|date=28 September 2012}}</ref> However, the correlation between circulation statistics and library classification scheme is not easy to demonstrate.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Morson|first1=Ian|last2=Perry|first2=Mike|title=Alternative Arrangement: New Approaches to Public Libraries Stock|date=1982|publisher=Association of Assistant Librarians|location=London|chapter=Two-Tier and Total: Stock Arrangement in Brent}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Miller|first1=Andrew|title=Alternative Arrangement in Glasgow City Libraries|journal=Public Library Journal|date=1992|volume=7|issue=5|pages=131–133}}</ref> Dewey-free reclassification projects are often undertaken in conjunction with other projects that aim to better merchandise a library's holdings, so it can be very unclear how much of a circulation increase can be attributed to a new classification scheme.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hill|first1=Nanci Milone|title=Dewey or Don't We?|journal=Public Libraries|date=July–August 2010|volume=49|issue=4|page=20}}</ref> Furthermore, library scholars typically warn against using circulation statistics as the sole metric of any project's success, because such statistics fail to account for materials used within the library, materials that were circulated but never read, or materials that were circulated but failed to provide users with the information they needed.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Spiller|first1=David|title=Providing Materials for Library Users|date=2000|publisher=Library Association Publishing|location=London|page=75}}</ref>
Call numbers are generally not indexed by [[Integrated Library System]]s, so the adoption of word-based classification systems has had little impact on [[information retrieval]] quality within library catalogs to date.<ref>{{cite conference | url=http://media.sois.uwm.edu/v/ea51a00429ec43c2993b1c5513477bf7 | title=Information Retrieval with BISAC in Bookstore, Library, and Other Catalogs | publisher=School of Information Studies, UW-Milwaukee | accessdate=18 June 2014 | author=Martinez Ávila, Daniel | year=2012}}</ref>
==Criticisms==
Critics of the new systems argue that BISAC's broad categories actually impede browsing, as many different subtopics are interspersed with one another. They prefer DDC's arrangement of materials by specific subject. They also argue that many of the issues addressed by Dewey-free systems could be resolved much more easily with improved signage and book labels.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stauffer|first1=Suzanne M.|title=Dewey - or Don't We - Classify?|journal=Children & Libraries|date=Summer 2008|volume=6|issue=2|pages=49–51}}</ref>
Even proponents of Dewey-free systems note that BISAC-based classification systems would be unsuitable for libraries with large or specialized collections.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=Jeff|title=Doing it without Dewey: A Perry Branch Library Tour|url=http://gathernodust.blogspot.com/2007/07/doing-it-without-dewey-perry-branch.html|website=Gather No Dust|accessdate=13 June 2014}}</ref> Critics have also questioned the pedagogical value of Dewey-free classifications, questioning whether library patrons used to a Dewey-free system will have the skills necessary to navigate collections classified according to DDC or [[Library of Congress Classification]].<ref name=metis />
Critics have also noted that using English words instead of numbers for all classification sends a message that libraries are only interested in serving English speakers.<ref name=lj />

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox court case | name = Dundee Farm Ltd v. Bambury Holdings Ltd | court = High Court of New Zealand | image = Coat of arms of New Zealand.svg | date_filed = | date decided = 30 July 1978 | full name = Dundee Farm Ltd v. Bambury Holdings Ltd | citations = [1978] 1 NZLR 647 | judges = Coates J | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | Legislation_cited= | opinions = | transcripts = | Keywords = mistake }} '''''Dundee Farm Ltd. v. Bambury Holdings Ltd.''''' (1978) is a case involving the sale of a farm in [[Bombay, South Auckland]] and is notable as it is often cited in New Zealand on issues of mistake,<ref name="Gerbic & Lawrence">{{cite book |title=Understanding Commercial Law |edition=5th |last1=Gerbic |first1=Philippa |last2=Lawrence |first2=Martin |publisher=LexisNexis |ISBN=0-408-71714-9|year=2003 |page=}}</ref><ref name="Walker">{{cite book |title=Butterworths Student Companion Contract |edition=4th |last1=Walker |first1=Campbell |publisher=LexisNexis |ISBN=0-408-71770-X|year=2004 |page=130}}</ref> and reinforces the English case of [[Joscelyne v Nissen]] [1970] 2 QB 86 into NZ case law.
==Background== The vendor's intention was to sell their {{convert|544|acre}} of farmland. Unfortunately, the subsequent sale agreement was complicated by the fact that the 544 acres was on numerous titles, and by mistake the vendor's solicitors included in the sale agreement a title for a {{convert|12|acre}} block, on the mistaken belief that these 12 acres were the south western corner of the farm.
It however transpired that these extra 12 acres were not only not the south western corner of the farm, it was not even near the farm, and was instead the vendor's residential lifestyle block {{convert|3|mi}} away in [[Pukekohe]].
When the vendor notified the purchaser of this mistake, the purchaser refused to settle on the sale contract, upon which the vendor brought an action for [[Rectification (law)|rectification]] and [[specific performance]].
==Held== The [[High Court of New Zealand]] ruled that as it was a pure mistake that the extra title was included, and that the purchaser's position had not changed, they ruled in favour of both rectification and for specific performance.

{{for|the train device|End-of-train device}} {{lowercase}} {{More citations needed|date=April 2009}} '''eOTD''' is the acronym for the '''ECCMA Open Technical Dictionary'''. The dictionary is a language-independent database of [[concept]]s with associated terms, definitions and images used to unambiguously describe individuals, organizations, locations, goods, services, processes, rules, and regulations. The eOTD is maintained by the [[Electronic Commerce Code Management Association]] ([[ECCMA]]).
== History == The eOTD was developed with the support of the Defense Logistics Information Service (DLIS) an agency of the US Defense Logistics Agency (DLA).<ref> {{cite conference | first = Peter | last = Benson | title = Using International Standards to drive the Federal Data Quality Process | booktitle = Proceedings of the MIT 2007 Information Quality Industry Symposium | pages = 623–639 | publisher = MIT | date = July 19, 2007 | location = Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA | url = http://mitiq.mit.edu/IQIS/Documents/CDOIQS_200777/Papers/01_35_3B.pdf | accessdate = 2013-03-12}} </ref> The eOTD is the first dictionary to be compliant with [[ISO 22745]]<ref> {{cite journal | last = Arnett | first = Steven | last2 = Benson | first2 = Peter | title = Federal Catalog System Proposed as New ISO Standard 22745 | journal = Defense Standardization Program Journal | pages = 16–20
| date = April–June 2005 | url = http://www.dsp.dla.mil/APP_UIL/content/newsletters/journal/DSPJ-04-05.pdf | accessdate = 2013-03-12}} </ref> (open technical dictionaries).
== Structure == The eOTD contains terms, definitions and images linked to concept identifiers.<ref> {{cite journal | last = de Jager | first = Salomon | title = Solving Data Quality Problems Using Data Standards | journal = Logistics Spectrum | volume = 41 | issue = 4 | pages = 7–10
| date = October–December 2007}} </ref> eOTD concept identifiers are used to create unambiguous language independent descriptions of individuals, organizations, locations, goods, services, processes, rules and regulations. The process of using concept identifiers from an external open technical dictionary is a form of semantic encoding compliant with the requirements of [[ISO 8000]]-110:2008, the international standard for the exchange of quality master data.
The eOTD concept identifiers are in the public domain. Using public domain identifiers as metadata creates portable data that can be legally separated from the software application that was used to create it. The dictionary contains concepts from international, national and industry standards including over 400,000 concepts of class (approved item name), property (attribute), units of measure, currency and common enumerated value (e.g., days of the week). The eOTD does not include a class hierarchy or class-property relationships.
== Use == Companies use the eOTD to create data requirement specifications as Identification Guides (IGs) or cataloging templates. These Identification Guides contain the class-property relationships and are used for cataloging, to measure data quality as well as to create requests for data or requests for data validation.

{{Redirect|Empire (magazine)|the defunct magazine|Empire (South African magazine)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Refimprove|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox Magazine |title = Empire |image_file = Empire cover Harry Potter July 2011.jpg |image_size = 220px |image_caption = Cover of the July 2011 issue, featuring [[Emma Watson]], [[Daniel Radcliffe]], and [[Rupert Grint]] |editor = Terri White |frequency = Monthly |category = Film |company = [[Bauer Verlagsgruppe|Bauer]] |firstdate = {{start date and age|1989|7}} |country = United Kingdom |circulation = 123,004 (Jul - Dec 2016){{cite web|title=ABC Certificates and Reports: Empire|url=https://www.abc.org.uk/product/5187-empire|publisher=[[Audit Bureau of Circulations (UK)|Audit Bureau of Circulations]] (ABC)|accessdate=12 March 2017}}
Print and digital editions. |circulation_year= |language = English |website = {{URL|empireonline.com}} |issn = 0957-4948 }} '''''Empire''''' is a British [[film magazine]] published monthly by [[Bauer Verlagsgruppe|Bauer Consumer Media]] of [[Hamburg]] based [[Bauer Media Group]]. From the first issue in July 1989, the magazine was edited by [[Barry McIlheney]] and published by [[Emap]]. [[Bauer Verlagsgruppe|Bauer]] purchased [[Emap|Emap Consumer Media]] in early 2008. Published in the [[United Kingdom]], ''Empire'' organises the annual [[Empire Awards]] which were sponsored by [[Sony Ericsson]], and from 2009 sponsored by [[Jameson Irish Whiskey|Jameson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/awards2009/|title=Jameson Empire Awards 2009 website |website=Empireonline.com|accessdate=16 October 2012}} The awards are voted for by readers of the magazine. ==Regular features== ''Empire'' reviews both mainstream films and [[art film]]s, but feature articles concentrate on the former. As well as film news, previews, and reviews, ''Empire'' has some other regular features. Each issue (with the exception of issues 108–113) features a ''Classic Scene'', a transcript from a notable film scene. The first such classic scene to be featured was the "I could have been a contender" scene from ''[[On the Waterfront]]''. The regular ''Top 10'' feature lists ''Empire''{{-'}}s choice of the top ten examples of something film-related. For example, ''10 Best Chase Scenes'' or ''10 Best Movie Gags in [[The Simpsons]]''. The ''Re.View'' section covers Blu-ray and DVD news and releases. ''Kim Newman's Movie Dungeon'' is a regular feature in the ''Re.View'' section, in which critic [[Kim Newman]] reviews the most obscure releases, mostly low budget horror movies. ''How Much Is A Pint Of Milk?'' presents celebrities' answers to silly or unusual questions, including the question "How much is a pint of milk?" This is intended as a guide to the chosen celebrity's contact with reality, and as such can be more informative than a direct interview by reporting some surprising responses. Each magazine includes a "Spine Quote", in which a relatively challenging quote is printed on the spine of the magazine. There are usually some obvious and obscure links from the quote to the main features of that month's edition. Readers are invited to identify the film source and the links to win a prize. ''My Movie Mastermind'' is another regular in which a celebrity is given questions about the films they were in or they directed. Celebrities range from [[Quentin Tarantino]] and [[Christopher Lee]] (who are at the top of the scoreboard) to [[John Carpenter]] and [[Michael Keaton]] (who are at the bottom of the scoreboard). ===The Empire Masterpiece=== A regular feature since issue 167, the Empire Masterpiece is a two-page essay on a film selected by Empire in the ''Re.View'' section. The selection of the films seem to be quite random and follow no specific pattern. Only a few issues since the first masterpiece feature have not featured one – 169, 179, 196, 197, 198 and 246. The '''Gazetteer of Australia''' is an index or dictionary of the location and spelling of geographical names across [[Australia]]. Geographic names include towns, suburbs and roads, plus geographical features such as hills, rivers, and lakes.
The index is compiled by the [[Intergovernmental Committee on Surveying and Mapping]] (ICSM) from determinations made by state, territory, and [[Government of Australia|Australian government]] agencies.
The authorities that work on geographic names in Australia are as follows: <!-- URLs added below based upon http://www.australiangeographic.com.au/journal/its-all-in-a-name.htm but it is out of date. -->
* [[Australian Capital Territory]] - National Memorials Committee - National Memorials Ordinance 1928<ref>[http://www.actpla.act.gov.au/tools_resources/maps_land_survey/place_names/place_names_committee ACT Place Names Committee] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130419123726/http://www.actpla.act.gov.au/tools_resources/maps_land_survey/place_names/place_names_committee |date=2013-04-19 }}</ref> * [[New South Wales]] - [[Geographical Names Board of New South Wales]]<ref>[http://www.gnb.nsw.gov.au/ Geographical Names Board of New South Wales]</ref> - [http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/consol_act//gna1966158/ Geographical Names Act, 1966] * [[Northern Territory]] - Place Names Committee for the Northern Territory - Place Names Act 1978<ref>[http://www.nt.gov.au/placenames/ Place Names Committee for the Northern Territory]</ref> * [[Queensland]] - [[Department of Natural Resources and Mines]] manages [[Queensland place names]] - Queensland Place Names Act 1988<ref>[http://www.derm.qld.gov.au/property/place_names.html Queensland place names] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130304114552/http://www.derm.qld.gov.au/property/place_names.html |date=2013-03-04 }}</ref> * [[South Australia]] - Geographical Names Board of South Australia - Act 101 1969<ref>[http://www.placenames.sa.gov.au/ Place Names SA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517083043/http://www.placenames.sa.gov.au/ |date=2008-05-17 }}</ref> * [[Tasmania]] - Nomenclature Board of Tasmania - Survey Co-ordination Act 1944 amendments of 1955 and 1964<ref>[http://www.thelist.tas.gov.au/ The List]</ref> * [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] - Place Names Committee - Survey Co-ordination (Place Names) Act 1965, updated to Geographic Place Names Act 1998<ref>{{cite web|title=VICNAMES |url=http://services.land.vic.gov.au/vicnames/ |work=Land.vic.gov.au |publisher=State of Victoria |accessdate=31 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111019160409/http://services.land.vic.gov.au/vicnames/ |archivedate=19 October 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://services.land.vic.gov.au/vicnames/ VICNAMES] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111019160409/http://services.land.vic.gov.au/vicnames/ |date=2011-10-19 }}</ref> * [[Western Australia]] - Geographic Names Committee<ref>{{cite web|title=Geographic Names Committee |url=http://www.landgate.wa.gov.au/corporate.nsf/web/Geographic+Names+Committee |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070611150232/http://www.landgate.wa.gov.au/corporate.nsf/web/Geographic+Names+Committee |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 June 2007 |work=Landgate |publisher=Landgate |accessdate=31 October 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.landgate.wa.gov.au/corporate.nsf/web/Western+Australian+Place+Names+and+Addressing Western Australian Place Names and Addressing] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622145427/http://www.landgate.wa.gov.au/corporate.nsf/web/Western%20Australian%20Place%20Names%20and%20Addressing |date=2013-06-22 }}</ref> - Land Administration Act 1997<ref>{{cite web|title=Legislation that supports geographic naming procedures |url=http://www.landgate.wa.gov.au/corporate.nsf/web/Legislation+That+Supports+Geographic+Naming+Procedures |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070901015032/http://www.landgate.wa.gov.au/corporate.nsf/web/Legislation+That+Supports+Geographic+Naming+Procedures |dead-url=yes |archive-date=1 September 2007 |work=Landgate |publisher=Landgate |accessdate=31 October 2011 |df= }}</ref> (originally the Nomenclature Advisory Committee, appointed in 1936)
As of January 2012, there are 370,000 place names in Australia. These are searchable in an online database hosted by [[Geoscience Australia]] and the entire data set can be purchased from the same organisation, with the 2010 version being available for [https://data.gov.au/dataset/gazetteer-of-australia-2010-release download].
==See also== *[[Committee for Geographical Names in Australasia]] *[[Suburbs and localities (Australia)]]

{{Infobox website |name = Google News Archive |logo = Google-News logo.png |logo_size = 200px |screenshot = |caption = |url = {{URL|https://news.google.com/newspapers}} |commercial = |type = [[Digital library|Newspaper archive]] |language = English, German, French, Spanish, Italian, Polish, Portuguese, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Dutch, Arabic, Hebrew, Norwegian, Czech, Hungarian, Swedish, Greek, Russian, Hindi, Telugu, Tamil, Turkish, and Malayalam. |registration = Not required |dissolved = yes |owner = |author = [[Google]] |launch date = {{Start date and age|2006|06|06}} |revenue = |current_status = Scanning project discontinued; search function "facelift" is "in the works" }} '''Google News Archive''' is an extension of [[Google News]] providing free access to scanned [[archives]] of newspapers and links to other [[newspaper]] archives on the web, both free and paid.
Some of the news archives date back to 1700s. There is a timeline view available, to select news from various years.
==History== The archive went live on June 6, 2006, after Google acquired [[PaperofRecord.com]], originally created by [[Robert J. Huggins]] and his team at Cold North Wind, Inc. The acquisition was not publicly announced by Cold North Wind until 2008.
While the service initially provided a simple index of other web pages, on September 8, 2008, Google News began to offer indexed content from scanned newspapers.<ref>{{cite web |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Bringing history online, one newspaper at a time|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2008/09/bringing-history-online-one-newspaper.html |quote=Today, we're launching an initiative to make more old newspapers accessible and searchable online by partnering with newspaper publishers to digitize millions of pages of news archives.|publisher=[[Google]] |date=September 8, 2008 |accessdate=2008-09-08 }}</ref> The depth of chronological coverage varies. Since 2008, the entire content of ''[[The New York Times]]'' back to its founding in 1851 has been available.
Newspapers were thought to have escaped copyright obligations of news articles because of Google's method of publishing the archives as searchable image files of the actual newspaper pages, rather than as pure text of articles.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
In 2011, Google announced that it would no longer add content to the archive project.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Google Ending Newspaper Archiving Project |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2385664,00.asp |quote=According to the Boston Phoenix, a paper that has been archived through the project, Google sent participants an email on Thursday informing them of its plans. Google told the paper it will shift its focus to "newer projects that help the industry, such as Google One Pass, a platform that enables publishers to sell content and subscriptions directly from their own sites." |newspaper=[[PC Magazine]] |date=May 20, 2011 |accessdate=2011-05-20 |first=Leslie |last=Horn}}</ref> On August 14, 2011, without notice, Google made the News Archives home page unavailable. Apparently, the service merged with [[Google News]].<ref>[http://www.netforlawyers.com/content/google-news-archive-search-integrated-news-search-advanced-search-0032 "Google Integrates News Archive Search Into Current News Search, Weakens Archive Search"]. ''Internet for Lawyers''</ref> Carly Carlioi, an editor at the ''[[Boston Phoenix]]'', speculated that Google discontinued the project because they found it harder than expected, for newspapers were more difficult to index than books because of layout complexities.<ref>{{cite news |work=[[The Atlantic]] |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2011/05/google-shuts-down-newspaper-archive-project/239239/ |title=Google Shuts Down Newspaper Archive Project |author=Jared Keller |date=May 20, 2011}}</ref> Another cause might have been that the project attracted a lesser audience than expected.
While archived newspapers<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers|title=Google News Archive Search|publisher=}}</ref> are still available for browsing, keyword searching is not fully functional. On December 16, 2013, Google News employee [[Stacie Chan]] wrote in the [[Google Product Forums]] that Google News is "performing a much needed facelift on our News Archive search function", and that access to archived stories would be limited for several months while "this new system" is being built.<ref>{{cite web |first=Stacie |last=C. |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Google News Archive update|url=https://productforums.google.com/d/msg/news/Gl23RwnTIlg/aAGakhzIe_cJ |publisher=[[Google Product Forums]] |date=December 16, 2013 |accessdate=2013-12-17 }}</ref> This was reaffirmed on May 22 and July 30, 2014, when Chan wrote that Google is still "working on the archives to provide a better user experience",<ref>{{cite web |first=Stacie |last=C. |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Google News Archive Search update...|url=https://productforums.google.com/d/msg/news/d_ZWZCTSWfc/RFjemwjUIqwJ |publisher=[[Google Product Forums]] |date=May 22, 2014 |accessdate=2014-05-22 }}</ref> and "it's in the works",<ref>{{cite web |first=Stacie |last=C. |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Google News Archive Search update...|url=https://productforums.google.com/forum/#!searchin/news/archive$20timeline/news/LrLLBZ-jjFA/8Ox4-Kwt7LEJ |publisher=[[Google Product Forums]] |date=August 10, 2014 |accessdate=2014-08-10 }}</ref> and again on December 18, 2014, when Chan wrote that Google "is currently working on creating a better experience on the Newspaper Archives that should be available in the near future."<ref>{{cite web |first=Stacie |last=C. |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Google News Archive Search update...|url=https://productforums.google.com/d/msg/news/Fw2caKy67LM/YZHQD_37kT4J |publisher=[[Google Product Forums]] |date=December 18, 2014 |accessdate=2015-06-23 }}</ref>
Some papers formerly included in the News Archive have been removed because of copyright issues. For instance, the archives of the ''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]'' disappeared on August 16, 2016, due to a contract between the paper's owner, the [[Gannett Company]], and [[NewsBank, inc.]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://urbanmilwaukee.com/2016/08/19/journal-sentinel-archive-disappears/|title=Journal Sentinel Archive Disappears|last=Takach|first=Michail|publisher=Urban Milwaukee|date=August 19, 2016|accessdate=2016-08-20}}</ref> although the archives were eventually restored.

[[File:Hut6.jpg|thumb|Hut 6 at Bletchley Park in 2004]] {{EnigmaSeries}} '''Hut 6''' was a wartime section of the [[Government Communications Headquarters#Government Code and Cypher School (GC&CS)|Government Code and Cypher School (GC&CS)]] at [[Bletchley Park]], [[Buckinghamshire]], [[UK|Britain]], tasked with the solution of German Army and Air Force [[Enigma machine]] cyphers. [[Hut 8]], by contrast, attacked Naval Enigma. Hut 6 was established at the initiative of [[Gordon Welchman]], and was run initially by Welchman and fellow [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] mathematician [[John R.F. Jeffreys|John Jeffreys]].
Welchman's deputy, [[Stuart Milner-Barry]], succeeded Welchman as head of Hut 6 in September 1943, at which point over 450 people were working in the section.<ref name="odnb">Ralph Erskine, ''Barry, Sir (Philip) Stuart Milner- (1906–1995)'', [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]], 2004.</ref>
Hut 6 was partnered with [[Hut 3]], which handled the translation and intelligence analysis of the raw decrypts provided by Hut 6.
==Location== Hut 6 was originally named after the building in which the section was located. Welchman says the hut was 20 yards (18m) long by 10 yards (9m) wide, with two large rooms at the far end – and no toilets. Staff had to go to another building. Irene Young recalled that she "worked in Room 82, though in typical Bletchley fashion there were not eighty-one rooms preceding it". She was glad to move from the Decoding Room "where all the operators were constantly having nervous breakdowns on account of the pace of work and the appalling noise" to the Registration Room which arranged intercepts according to callsign and frequency <ref>Young (1990) p 74</ref>
As the number of personnel increased, the section moved to additional buildings around Bletchley Park, but its name was retained, with each new location also being known as 'Hut 6'. The original building was then renamed 'Hut 16'.
==Personnel== [[John R.F. Jeffreys|John Jeffreys]] was initially in charge of the Hut with [[Gordon Welchman]] until May 1940; Jeffreys was diagnosed ill in 1940, and died in 1944. Welchman became official head of section until autumn 1943, subsequently rising to Assistant Director of Mechanisation at Bletchley Park. [[Conel Hugh O'Donel Alexander|Hugh Alexander]], was a member February 1940 – March 1941 before moving to become head of [[Hut 8]]. [[Stuart Milner-Barry]] joined early 1940 and was in charge from autumn 1943 to the end of the war.
One codebreaker concerned with [[Cryptanalysis of the Enigma]], [[John Herivel]], discovered what was soon dubbed the '''Herivel tip''' or '''Herivelismus'''. For a brief but critical few months from May 1940, the "tip", in conjunction with operating shortcomings or "[[Cryptanalysis of the Enigma#Operating shortcomings|cillies]]", were the main techniques used to solve Enigma. The "tip" was an insight into the habits of the German machine operators allowing Hut 6 to easily deduce part of the daily [[key (cryptography)|key]].
In 1942, Welchman recruited fellow [[Marlborough Collegers]], [[Bob Roseveare]] and Nigel Forward. Roseveare started in the ''Watch'' working on Luftwaffe messages before moving to the ''Quatch'', a small backroom group that decoded non-current messages.
In Hut 6 were the Machine Room, plus the Decoding Room and Registration Room with mainly female staff under Harold Fletcher, a school and university friend of Gordon Welchman.<ref>Briggs (2011), p 84-85</ref><ref>Welchman (1982) p 103-4</ref> In 2014 one of these female staff, [[Mair Russell-Jones]], published a posthumous memoir of her work there.<ref>Robin Turner, [http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/mair-russell-jones-headhunted-bletchley-7509061 "Bletchley Park uncovered: The secret life of the Welsh World War II codebreaker"], Wales Online, July 27, 2014.</ref>
Other notable individuals include:
* [[Alexander Aitken]], New Zealand and Scottish mathematician<ref>[[J. M. Whittaker]], ‘Aitken, Alexander Craig (1895–1967)’, rev. Anita McConnell, [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]], [[Oxford University Press]], 2004; online edn, May 2006.</ref> * [[James Macrae Aitken]], Scottish chess player * Madge E. Allen<ref name="BPT">{{cite web|title=Bletchley Park {{!}} Roll of Honour — undefined|url=https://bletchleypark.org.uk/roll-of-honour/113|website=Bletchley Park|publisher=Bletchley Park Trust|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> * [[Dennis Babbage]] * Clarence Barasch, American observer to British Intelligence{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} * [[Asa Briggs]], English historian * June Canney, Registration Room later Welchman's secretary <ref>Welchman (1982) p 86-7</ref> * John Coleman and George Crawford, Intercept Control Room.<ref>Welchman (1982) p 84</ref> * Harold Fletcher, administrator{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} * [[Edna Garbutt]], member of A watch{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} * [[Jane Hughes Fawcett|Jane Hughes]], later Jane Hughes Fawcett, who decoded the message that led to the sinking of the [[German battleship Bismarck]] * [[Ione Roseveare|Ione Jay]], (Ione Roseveare) wrote an account of her experiences there * [[Oliver Lawn]], married 1948 Sheila who worked elsewhere at BP, Scottish country dancer.<ref>Briggs (2011) p 8, 45</ref> * [[Reginald H. Parker]], discoverer of "Parkerismus"{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} * [[David Rees (mathematician)|David Rees]], University of Exeter mathematics professor * [[Derek Taunt]], Cambridge research student * [[Irene Brown|Irene Young]], University of Edinburgh, Decoding Room then Registration Room{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} * Helen C. Stanley-Baker, Oxford mathematics student<ref>[http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/resources/filer.rhtm/591884/s Bletchley Park Summary of Service], 2013</ref> * [[Ann Katharine Mitchell]] (nee Williamson), Oxford mathematics graduate

H. Hinsley, and Alan Stripp, [[Oxford University Press]], 2003 * Mair and Gethin Russell-Jones, ''My Secret Life in Hut Six: One woman’s experiences at Bletchley Park'' (2014; Lion Hudson, Oxford) {{ISBN|978 0 7459 5664 0}} * Derek Taunt, "Hut 6: 1941-1945", pp. 100–112 in ''Codebreakers: The Inside Story of Bletchley Park', edited by F. H. Hinsley, and Alan Stripp, Oxford University Press, 2003 * Gordon Welchman, ''The Hut Six Story: Breaking the Enigma Codes'' (1982: London, [[Allen Lane]] & New York, [[McGraw-Hill]]) {{ISBN|0-7139-1294-4}} * Gordon Welchman, ''The Hut Six Story: Breaking the Enigma Codes'' (1997: [[Cleobury Mortimer]], Baldwin) {{ISBN|978-0-947712-34-1}} * Irene Young, ''Enigma Variations: A Memoir of Love and War'' (1990, [[Mainstream Publishing]], Edinburgh) {{ISBN|1-85158-294-0}} *[http://www.maths.ed.ac.uk/~aar/turingletter.pdf Alan Turing, Gordon Welchman, Hugh Alexander, Stuart Milner-Barry.
